div: Overview This tab allows you to select which spectrum file is displayed for each role (foreground, background, secondary), and if a file has multiple samples, which samples to sum together for display.

div:
InterSpecs Memory Model When you load a spectrum file into InterSpec, either through dragging-and-dropping the file into InterSpec, or opening it through the menu, all previous spectra you have open, and all your changes to them stay in memory. That is, using the Spectrum Files tab, or the Spectrum Manager, can can switch between spectrum files without losing work you've done, like peaks being fit, activity/source models fit, or energy calibrations.
Spectrum files may contain many spectrum within them, maybe from multiple detectors, and/or from multiple different points in times. Each set of spectra within a file with a specific start time are assigned a sample number when loading. So if a spectrum file contains data from multiple detectors, like an RPM or search system might, the spectra from each detector will typically be synchronized in time, so the spectra from all detectors that start at the same time, will have the same sample number. A combination of a sample number and detector name (see the "View" → "Detectors" menu) will uniquely specify a single spectrum in a spectrum file.
InterSpec associates peaks fit for a foreground with the foreground file and set of sample numbers currently being shown. So if you change the sample numbers being shown, your previous peaks will no longer be visible; however, if you switch back to the original sample number(s), your previously fit peaks will be displayed again.

Specifying Sample Numbers If the currently selected spectrum file contains multiple samples, you can choose which ones are used for displaying of the spectrum. If you select multiple time samples, they will be summed together.
An example of selecting multiple samples is if you enter the text: "1-4,8,10,13-44".
This selects samples 1 through 4, 8, 10, and 13 through 44 to be summed together before being displayed for analysis.
If the spectrum file is from a search system or radiation portal monitor, a chart with the time history of gamma and neutron counts will be displayed; that chart lets you use your mouse and modification keys (e.g., shift, option, alt) to interactively select the samples to use as foreground and background; when using the time chart to select regions to use, the sample numbers on this Spectrum Files tool will automatically be updated.

Scale Factor By default, the background and secondary spectra will be live-time normalized to the foreground when loaded. For example, if the live-time of the background is twice as long as the foreground, a scale factor of 0.5 will be applied to the number of counts in each channel of the background spectrum when its display. This is usually what you want as it makes the two spectrums easily visually compared. However, there are times when you will want to manually adjust this, like if the foreground was taken in a different location than the background, so you need to scale the background spectrum to account for higher or lower terrestrial radiation rates. You can do this by manually changing the scale factor on this Spectrum Files tab, or, more conveniently, you can graphically alter the scale factor by selecting the "Show Y-Axis Scalers" options from the "View" menu, which will then display some sliders on the spectrum chart that you can drag to do the adjustment in a more intuitive way.

Additional Buttons The "Spectrum Manager..." and "Previous..." buttons on this tab will bring up dialogs that allow you to, respectively, perform more advanced spectrum file selection and manipulation, or browse InterSpecs internal database for previously saved spectra.
